subdebateinfo.title: National Museum of Australia: Acquisition of Boomerang

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts, in writing, on 15 September 2008:

item.para: Could he advise what action has been taken following my request on 21 August 2008 for the Australian Government to bid at the auction in London by Christie’s on 25 September 2008, for a boomerang that is believed to have been acquired by Captain James Cook on his voyage to New Holland in the Endeavour in 1770.

Specifically, could he advise what representations have been made to the British Government to seek its support to acquire the boomerang and return it to Australia as a gesture of good will; if no such representations have been made, why not.
Could he provide detailed information on:

item.label: (a)
item.para: any investigations that have been made by the Australian Government and its related agencies to acquire the boomerang directly at auction; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: the results of any inquiries undertaken regarding the authenticity of the item.

talker.name: Garrett, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts
talker.name: Mr Garrett

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The National Museum of Australia undertook a thorough investigation of the provenance of the boomerang and two clubs to be auctioned. The Museum could find no direct link between these items and Captain James Cook.
The Australian Government did not make a representation to the British Government prior to the National Museum of Australia concluding its research on the boomerang and the clubs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 15 September 2008:

item.para: Since November 2007, has his office received representations from the New South Wales (NSW) Premier or NSW Government ministers and their departments regarding the extension of the Southern Freeway (F6).
Has his office received representations from Federal Members of Parliament representing the Illawarra region regarding the feasibility study into the F6 extension.
Is either the Princes Highway or F6 defined by his department or Infrastructure Australia as ‘nationally significant’ for the purposes of Infrastructure Australia’s national audit of infrastructure.

talker.name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
talker.name: Mr Albanese

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: I have, and continue to, receive many submissions from state and local government, community groups and local, state and federal Members of Parliament about numerous projects across Australia. The Government has established Infrastructure Australia (IA), an independent statutory advisory council, to provide advice to the Australian Government about infrastructure gaps and bottlenecks that hinder economic growth and prosperity. IA will also identify investment priorities, and propose policy and regulatory reforms necessary to deliver timely and coordinated national infrastructure investment or improve the efficient utilisation of existing infrastructure.

To meet its goal of facilitating public discussion about how the planning, investment in and use of nationally significant infrastructure can be improved, IA has called for submissions from industry and the community. As part of this process, IA has released two discussion papers on Australia’s Future Requirements and on Public Private Partnerships. The papers are available on the IA website <www.infrastructureaustralia.gov.au>. Submissions are due to Infrastructure Australia no later than 15 October 2008, for consideration in the development of the National Public Private Partnership Guidelines and National Infrastructure Audit.
I would encourage you and your constituents to make submissions as part of this process.
